subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: "temple carving" on tsuba

I believe you pictured the tsuba upside down, so whatever is there needs to be looked at after the tsuba is rotated 180 degrees. It my be a Buddhist symbol that looks like a swastika or it may be something totally unrelated
 
Mark Jones
nixe@... 


  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: David Zincavage 
  To: token_kenkyu_kai@... 
  Cc: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Tuesday, August 05, 2003 3:31 PM
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: "temple carving" on tsuba


  But what are temple carvings?  Are they symbols of good luck placed on the tsuba to protect its owner? Or are they ownership marks indicating that sword and/or tsuba are the property of a particular temple? 

    ----- Original Message ----- 
    From: RDavis@... 
    To: token_kenkyu_kai@... 
    Sent: Tuesday, August 05, 2003 11:27 AM
    Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: "temple carving" on tsuba


    David....looks like the Buddhist symbol that is in the form of the German swastika only the "arms" are in the opposite direction.  I have a tachi tsuba that has this same symbol in sukashi style just outside the seppa dai area. 

     

    Roger

     

    -----Original Message-----
    From: David Zincavage [mailto:jdz@...]
    Sent: Tuesday, August 05, 2003 11:14 AM
    To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
    Cc: token_kenkyu_kai@...
    Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: "temple carving" on tsuba

     

    Whoops! I forgot to mention it is on the right side of the seppa dai.

    ----- Original Message ----- 


    From: David Zincavage

      Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: "temple carving" on tsuba


      --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "David Zincavage" <jdz@i...> 
      wrote:
      > I just bought a tsuba which the dealer describes as having " a 
      small 
      temple
      > carving symbol on the seppadai." I could not recognize it in the 
      pictures.
      > What sort of temple carvings appear on tsubas?

      On the seppa-dai ????

      All sorts of "real" and abstract temples are used
      as motifs on the body of the tsuba.

      A picture would be most helpful.

      Rich
